_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Moorhead Wastewater Treatment Plant (Facility) personnel in Moorhead, Minnesota take great pride in maintaining a safe operation for the employees, the community, and the environment. The primary focus is to prevent accidental releases before they occur, while providing systems that minimize the size of any release that does occur and contain it in as small as area as possible.
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES: It is Moorhead Wastewater Treatment Plant policy to operate its plants in a manner that protect its employees, the public, and the environment. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local laws. The facility has a detailed, practiced Emergency Response Plan that is utilized to respond to any accidental releases.
FACILITY DESCRIPTION: The Facility is a waste water treatment plant. Chlorine is used as a disinfectant in wastewater treatment and sulfur dioxide is used to dechlorinate the wastewater effluent stream.  Up to ten one-ton chlorine cylinders and ten one-ton sulfur dioxide cylinders are stored at the plant.
GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION
STEPS: The Facility has implemented the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard, which is a systematic method of preventing accidental releases and complies with EPA's accident prevention rule. As such, the facility has completed a detailed analysis on the process to ensure the safe use and operation of the applicable equipment. Numerous safeguards are in place and include Operational Procedures, manual control systems, vents and relief valves. The facility uses both procedural as well as technological systems to ensure safe handling of the toxic chemicals.
FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY: There have been no accidents within that past five years.
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM: In the event of an emergency involving the toxic chemicals, plant personnel will notify the Moorhead Fire and Rescue Department and rely on their exp

ertise to handle the situation. The Facility is included in the community emergency response plan.
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY: The Facility has an ongoing and continuing process to audit, update and review our process for safety considerations. Based upon this review the Facility will further investigate the buddy system for tank change outs to prevent the release of the toxic chemicals.
